newsitem.title: DUBAI: Frankfurt/Schiphol seek Euro-rail standards for air cargo.
newsitem.headline: Frankfurt/Schiphol seek Euro-rail standards for air cargo.

text.p: Frankfurt airport (FAG) and its Dutch counterpart, Amsterdam-Schiphol have set up a joint working group to study the development of rail services for the air cargo industry, Frankfurt airport said in a statement released here.

The main issues are the need for rapid progress, for co-ordination and standardisation -- so that there is a common European approach -- and ensuring the support of the Dutch and German governments, the statement added.
The first results of the working group's studies are expected to be presented at next September's International Frankfurt Air Days, it added.
However the scheme is not exclusive to the two airports and they welcomed any other interested parties, FAG's head of freight logistics marketing, Bernhard Lessman told Reuters.
"We aim to be a co-ordinator or moderator and provide an interface for dealing with the rail industry," he added.
The first step will be to launch a conventional service for the air cargo industry, as both airports expect the demand for faster and more frequent services to increase, the statement said.
"This train could be based on the recently launched German "Cargosprinter" service which is able to carry large containers," added Lessmann.
"But to make sure it is a success, we must get the cost of air cargo carried by rail down to the same level as that now carried by road," he added.

The working group's joint action programme has three primary issues, FAG said. These are the co-ordination of efforts towards a conventional air cargo shuttle train, the sharing of market information and establishing a joint view on future project developments.

Such projects include high speed freight trains, combi-trains and radically new transport systems, such as the underground cargo pipeline to move flowers between Schiphol, Dutch flower auctions and a future rail terminal near the airport.
